features.name: backbone
features.question: Does the animal have a backbone, spine, or notochord?

features.name: skeleton
features.question: Does the animal have an internal skeleton (or notochord) made of bone or cartilage?

features.name: skull
features.question: Does the animal have a head with a brain protected by a skull?

features.name: lack of tissues and organs
features.question: Does the animal lack true tissues or organs?

features.name: pores
features.question: Does the animal have a porous body with many small holes (pores)?

features.name: also lives in fresh water
features.question: Can the animal be found in fresh water?

features.name: milk feeding
features.question: Does the animal produce milk (NOT crop milk) to feed its young?

features.name: warm blooded
features.question: Does the animal have a constant body temperature (warm-blooded)?

features.name: hair fur
features.question: Does the animal have fur or hair?

features.name: underdeveloped young
features.question: Does the animal give birth to underdeveloped young that crawl into a pouch?

features.name: pouch
features.question: Does the animal have a pouch where the young develop after birth?

features.name: live birth
features.question: Does the animal give live birth (i.e., do the offspring develop inside the mother and are born alive, rather than hatching from eggs)?

features.name: fully developed young
features.question: Does the animal give birth to fully developed young (i.e., those that do not require nurturing outside the womb, such as in a pouch)?

features.name: placenta
features.question: Does the animal have a placenta to nourish the young during gestation (between conception and birth)?

features.name: chewing
features.question: Does the animal have specialized teeth for chewing or grinding food?

features.name: lay eggs
features.question: Does the animal lay eggs instead of giving live birth?

features.name: specialized glands
features.question: Does the animal have specialized mammary glands for producing milk, but no nipples?

features.name: live in water
features.question: Does the animal primarily live in water or burrow underground?

features.name: fins
features.question: Does the animal have fins instead of legs?

features.name: gills
features.question: Does the animal breathe with gills?

features.name: in water
features.question: Does the animal live in water?

features.name: sucker-like or slit-like mouth
features.question: Does the fish lack a jaw and have a round, sucker-like or slit-like mouth instead of teeth?

features.name: looks like an eel
features.question: Does it look like an eel, with smooth skin and no visible scales?

features.name: slim, elongated body
features.question: Does the fish have a slim, elongated body and appear to be more primitive compared to other fish?

features.name: feels rough like sandpaper
features.question: Does the fish have visible fins and jaws but feel rough like sandpaper, or seem to have no hard bones?

features.name: looks like a shark
features.question: Does it look like a shark, ray, or skate?

features.name: long, cylindrical body
features.question: Does the fish have a long, cylindrical body and appear to swim using side-to-side motions?

features.name: hard bones, shiny scales
features.question: Does the fish look like it has hard bones, scales that are smooth or shiny, and a wide variety of body shapes?

features.name: looks like common fish
features.question: Does it look like most common fish you would see in aquariums or when fishing?

features.name: streamlined or symmetrical body
features.question: Does the fish have a more streamlined or symmetrical body and often appear in schools or large groups?

features.name: both water land
features.question: Does the animal live both in water and on land at different stages of its life?

features.name: larva born
features.question: Does the animal start life as a larva or tadpole in water?

features.name: eggs in water
features.question: Does the animal lay eggs in water?

features.name: scaly skin
features.question: Does the animal have dry, scaly skin?

features.name: lungs
features.question: Does the animal breathe using lungs its entire life?

features.name: leathery eggs
features.question: Does the animal lay leathery or soft-shell eggs?

features.name: feathers
features.question: Does the animal have feathers?

features.name: beak
features.question: Does the animal have a beak or bill instead of teeth?

features.name: eggs hard shell
features.question: Does the animal lay eggs with hard shells?

features.name: unsegmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a soft, unsegmented body?

features.name: tentacles
features.question: Does the animal have a muscular foot or tentacles for movement?

features.name: mantle
features.question: Does the animal have a mantle (a tissue layer) that secretes a shell or protects internal organs?

features.name: segmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a segmented body?

features.name: jointed legs
features.question: Does the animal have jointed legs or appendages?

features.name: exoskeleton
features.question: Does the animal have an exoskeleton made of chitin?

features.name: aquatic
features.question: Does the animal live primarily in aquatic environments?

features.name: pairs of antennae
features.question: Does the animal have two pairs of antennae?

features.name: carapace
features.question: Does the animal have a hard exoskeleton (often called a carapace) covering its body?

features.name: segmented body with numerous legs
features.question: Does the animal have a long, segmented body with numerous legs?

features.name: pair of legs per segment
features.question: Does the animal have one or two pair of legs per segment

features.name: fangs or small mandibles
features.question: Does the animal have large fangs (for injecting venom) or smaller mandibles for grinding vegetation?

features.name: two segments
features.question: Does the animal have a body divided into two main segments (cephalothorax and abdomen)?

features.name: eight legs
features.question: Does the animal have four pairs of legs (eight legs total)?

features.name: pedipalps
features.question: Does the animal have specialized appendages called pedipalps near the mouth?

features.name: three segments
features.question: Does the animal have a body divided into three main segments: head, thorax, and abdomen?

features.name: six legs
features.question: Does the animal have three pairs of legs (six legs total)?

features.name: compound eyes and antennae
features.question: Does the animal have compound eyes and one pair of antennae?

features.name: endoskeleton
features.question: Does the animal have an endoskeleton made of ossicles?

features.name: water vascular system
features.question: Does the animal have a water vascular system?

features.name: radial symmetry
features.question: Does the animal have radial symmetry?

features.name: cnidocytes
features.question: Does the animal have stinging cells (cnidocytes)?

features.name: sac-like
features.question: Does the animal have a sac-like body with a single opening for food and waste?

features.name: sessile
features.question: Is the animal sessile (fixed in one place) for its entire life?

features.name: reefs
features.question: Does the animal form colonies that build reefs?

features.name: get energy from tiny plants
features.question: Does the animal get energy from tiny plants (algae) that live inside its body and help it make food?

features.name: freshwater
features.question: Does the animal live in freshwater (like lakes, rivers, or ponds) instead of the ocean?

features.name: regenerate
features.question: Does the animal regenerate when cut into pieces?

features.name: stay in one place
features.question: Does the animal stay in one place, attached to a surface (polyplop form), for its whole life instead of swimming freely?

features.name: bell-shaped
features.question: Does the animal have a bell-shaped medusa body form?

features.name: float-freely
features.question: Does the animal float freely in water currents?

features.name: stinging cells
features.question: Does the animal have tentacles with stinging cells used to capture prey?

features.name: unsegmented or segmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a long, soft body that is either unsegmented or segmented?

features.name: bilateral symmetry
features.question: Does the animal have bilateral symmetry?

features.name: lacks legs or appendages
features.question: Does the animal lack legs or appendages?

features.name: dorsoventrally flattened
features.question: Is the animal dorsoventrally flattened (flat body)?

features.name: lacks body cavity
features.question: Does the animal lack a body cavity (acoelomate)?

features.name: relies on diffusion for gas exchange
features.question: Does the animal rely on diffusion for gas exchange and waste removal?

features.name: cylindrical, unsegmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a cylindrical, unsegmented body?

features.name: complete digestive tract
features.question: Does the animal have a complete digestive tract with a separate mouth and anus?

features.name: parasite in mammals
features.question: Does the animal usually live as a parasite in the digestive system of mammals?

features.name: segmented body divided into repeating sections
features.question: Does the animal have a segmented body divided into repeating sections, like rings or segments?

features.name: circulatory system with blood vessels
features.question: Does the animal have a circulatory system with blood vessels?

features.name: tiny hair-like structures
features.question: Does the animal have tiny hair-like structures on its body that help it move?

Rules.end classification:
The animal is classified as a marsupial.
 Vertebrates → Mammals → Marsupials

The animal is classified as a placental mammal.
 Vertebrates → Mammals → Placentals

The animal is classified as a monotreme.
 Vertebrates → Mammals → Monotremes

The animal is classified as a jawless fish.
 Vertebrates → Fish → Jawless Fish

The animal is classified as a cartilaginous fish.
 Vertebrates → Fish → Cartilaginous Fish

The animal is classified as a bony fish.
 Vertebrates → Fish → Bony Fish

The animal is classified as a bird.
 Vertebrates → Birds

The animal is classified as a reptile.
 Vertebrates → Reptiles

The animal is classified as an amphibian.
 Vertebrates → Amphibians

The animal is classified as a sponge.
 Invertebrates → Sponges

The animal is classified as a coral.
 Invertebrates → Coelenterates → Coral

The animal is classified as a hydra.
 Invertebrates → Coelenterates → Hydra

The animal is classified as a jellyfish.
 Invertebrates → Coelenterates → Jellyfish

required features: relies on diffusion for gas exchange

Rules.end classification:
The animal is classified as a flatworm.
 Invertebrates → Worms → Flatworms

The animal is classified as a roundworm.
 Invertebrates → Worms → Roundworms

required features: segmented body divided into repeating sections

Rules.end classification:
The animal is classified as a segmented worm.
 Invertebrates → Worms → Segmented Worms

The animal is classified as a mollusk.
 Invertebrates → Mollusks

The animal is classified as a crustacean.
 Invertebrates → Arthropods → Crustaceans

The animal is classified as an arachnid.
 Invertebrates → Arthropods → Arachnids

The animal is classified as a myriapod.
 Invertebrates → Arthropods → Myriapods

The animal is classified as an insect.
 Invertebrates → Arthropods → Insects

The animal is classified as an echinoderm.
 Invertebrates → Echinoderms

Facts: relies on diffusion for gas exchange
segmented body divided into repeating sections
